Message.Title: Huge Fiscal Stimulus... MASSIVE monetary Stimulus... NO Growth.
Message.Msg: Our $1.2 Trillion federal deficits means that there is FAR more money being put in people's wallets thru government speinding than is being taken out of those wallets in taxes... ... in all past U.S. recoveries, that would result in a booming recovery and 7 to 10% GDP growth! The federal reserve has driven the fed funds rate to 0%... which is unprecedented in U.S. history. The Fed's QE3 is also driving long-term rates lower... THAT'S NEVER BEEN DONE BEFORE... ... that kind of monetary stimulus should be rocketing our economy higher! Yet, U.S. GDP is growing a 1.3% snail's pace... and is getting slower EVERY YEAR. The problem? America has elected it's first "anti-capitalist" president... and the result is that the powerful engine of capitalism has SEIZED UP in America. Over the past 100 years, this EXACT SAME THING has happened in countless socialist countries that came before us...... ...... ARE WE SO STUPID THAT WE HAVN'T LEARNED ANYTHING FROM THAT? 4 more years of THIS, and we're going down HARD... just like Greece!

Topic.Title: Huge Fiscal Stimulus... MASSIVE monetary Stimulus... NO Growth.

Message.Msg: ... for the sugar and the energy it provides while simultaneously delivering hydration at 13,000' elev. Otherwise, I'm an economist who understands the power of capitalism to build wealth and success in an economy as it did in America decades ago... ... and the power of socialism to curb capital deployment, encourage consumption, and run the national debt up to the levels of Greece. On it's current trajectory, the U.S. debt-to-GDP ratio will exceed that of Greece's in less than 4 years... which just happens to be the duration of the next presdent's term in office. The only proposal Obama has floated to curb that trajectory is to raise taxes on those with investment capital (eg: the wealthy), which will cut the deficit by $78 billion using a "static" model (dynamic modeling, which is more realistic, shows much less of a reduction to the deficit). That $78 billion constitutes about 1/15 of the current deficit. 4 more years of THAT means a hard-hard landing for the U.S. economy. Essentially Greece. S

Message.Title: IBM REPORTS 2012 THIRD-QUARTER RESULTS
Message.Msg: IBM REPORTS 2012 THIRD-QUARTER RESULTS · Diluted EPS: · GAAP: $3.33, up 4 percent; $3.44, up 8 percent excluding UK pension-related charges; · Operating (non-GAAP): $3.62, up 10 percent; · Net income: · GAAP: $3.8 billion, flat; $3.9 billion, up 3 percent excluding UK pension-related charges; · Operating (non-GAAP): $4.2 billion, up 5 percent; · Gross profit margin: · GAAP: 47.4 percent, up 0.9 points; · Operating (non-GAAP): 48.1 percent, up 1.2 points; · Revenue: $24.7 billion, down 5 percent, down 2 percent adjusting for currency; · Negative currency impact of nearly $1 billion; · Divestiture of Retail Store Solutions (RSS) reduced revenue by 1 percent; · Software revenue down 1 percent, up 3 percent adjusting for currency; · Services revenue down 5 percent, flat adjusting for currency; · Services backlog of $138 billion, up 1 percent; · Systems and Technology revenue down 13 percent, down 12 percent adjusting for currency; · Growth markets revenue down 1 percent, up 4 percent adjusting for currency; · BRIC countries up 4 percent, up 11 percent adjusting for currency; · Business analytics revenue up 14 percent year to date; · Smarter Planet revenue up more than 20 percent year to date; · Cloud revenue year to date has exceeded full-year 2011 revenue; · Reiterating full-year 2012 operating (non-GAAP) EPS expectation of at least $15.10. ARMONK, N.Y., October 16, 2012 . . . IBM (NYSE: IBM) today announced third-quarter 2012 diluted earnings of $3.33 per share, a year-to-year increase of 4 percent, or $3.44 per share, up 8 percent excluding the impact of UK pension-related charges. Operating (non-GAAP) diluted earnings were $3.62 per share, compared with operating diluted earnings of $3.28 per share in the third quarter of 2011, an increase of 10 percent. Third-quarter net income was $3.8 billion, flat year-to-year; or $3.9 billion, up 3 percent excluding the impact of UK pension-related charges. Operating (non-GAAP) net income was $4.2 billion compared with $4.0 billion in the third quarter of 2011, an increase of 5 percent. Total revenues for the third quarter of 2012 of $24.7 billion were down 5 percent (down 2 percent, adjusting for currency) from the third quarter of 2011. Currency negatively impacted revenue growth by nearly $1 billion. “In the third quarter, we continued to drive margin, profit and earnings growth through our focus on higher-value businesses, strategic growth initiatives and productivity,” said Ginni Rometty, IBM chairman, president and chief executive officer. “Looking ahead, we see good opportunity with a strong product lineup heading into this quarter and annuity businesses that provide a solid base of revenue, profit and cash. We are reiterating our full-year 2012 operating earnings per share expectation of at least $15.10.” Third-Quarter GAAP — Operating (non-GAAP) Reconciliation Third-quarter operating (non-GAAP) diluted earnings exclude $0.29 per share of charges: $0.12 per share for the amortization of purchased intangible assets and other acquisition-related charges, and $0.17 per share for retirement-related charges, including $0.11 per share for the impact of UK pension-related charges. sec

Message.Msg: Theater on fire run fior your lives ... stop at the lobby to pick a few shares cheap on a blue chip company that will exceed expectations as the sun comes up !!!

Message.Title: IBM need to changed their name to International Outsource Machine
Message.Msg: IBM management are the pro in doing the layoff of American white collar employees and replacing them with cheap indian labor, squeezing every drops of sweat from current IBM employees, no overtime pay to employee even if employee work their #$%$ off to hit the project target, multilayers of corporate bureaucracy management, no training & education provided to employee that need it,....etc. Talking about employee innovation and creative thinking ??? Forget about it. IBM is no way compared to Google or Apple.

Topic.Title: Ive seen it before

Message.Msg: A 1.6 percent dividend doesn't do much for me. Plenty of companies pay more. Playing the dip for the bounce.

Message.Title: Declining revenues for 5 q's in a row (on a yoy basis)...
Message.Msg: projecting 2013 earnings lighter than analysts and less than their last q brag about forward income...closing within dimes of an all time high with "growth" like that??? I think this company is priced to perfection and sub 190 may be in the cards over the next couple of months. The trillions that the gov't threw at big business is losing its' effectiveness and all this "growth" is a mere mirage imo. Bear markets are coming, did anybody hear the music stop or is it still playing? Grab your chair while you still can.

Message.Title: Hey, IBM&INTC Blow earnings & forcasts ... I'M SO BULLISH, MY EYEBALLS ARE FALLING OUT!!!
Message.Msg: What could be better that for 2 misses on earnings in techland and a fiscal cliff in U.S. about to slap american's in the face for 2 trillion in tax levies on middle class? I just went long U.S. stocks for first time in a year. Hey Chinese, Japanese and Spaniards, get up on this U.S. rally before the train leaves the station. ALL ABOARD TO HIGHER HIGHS BOYS AND GIRLS!!!

Topic.Title: Ive seen it before

Message.Msg: i back those words, just buy and never look back. 2013 and January's fiscal cliff is way out there. There shouldn't be much more than a 20 percent correction in early 2013.

Topic.Title: Ive seen it before

Message.Msg: My philosophy also. Let it ride. Tried playing the dips and I'm not that smart. Once I decided to hold, I've never looked back, doubling my money. So yeah it will probably drop to 200 tomorrow, maybe 195, but I'll bet you the ranch that in 2 weeks it's back up to 210.
